text: Wasn’t meant that way even remotely! Apologies if that’s what came through.
author: pilhofer

text:
Yeah, this is a completely irrelevant point anyway. Digital goods vs physical. Gucci stores are not remotely comparable to the NYT paywall. This is apples v helicopters. 

Seems like we agree on the relevant question, which is Apple News. So cool. Leave it there.
author: pilhofer

text: But for the Times? FT? WSJ? I can’t see a single reason to jump into Apple News under the terms as we understand them. This is one of those very very rare cases where Apple needs big publishers more than they need Apple. They should take advantage, IMO.
author: pilhofer

text:
Not saying publishers shouldn’t find additional/alternate channels. Absolutely they should. It’s more that this specific channel offers next to nothing for publishers like the NYT.

For Vox, which isn’t a subscription business, it makes sense. For smaller publishers, maybe.
author: pilhofer

text: I think you could even make a better case for Instant Articles, certainly for AMP, than Apple News. Apple takes all the customers. Apple controls that relationship. Apple controls the user experience, promotion, etc. And takes 50 percent off the top? For what?
author: pilhofer

text:
This is a silly analogy. The NYT is a different kind of business. So let’s just drop Gucci, ok?

I take your point about expanding the market for news, and offering additional sales channels. I don’t disagree. I just think the deal Apple is offering is a lousy one for publishers.
author: pilhofer

text: The equivalent here would be Gucci giving products to Macy’s. Macy’s charging customers a flat rate. Customers coming into the store taking whatever they want *regardless of the value of that thing* and Macy’s giving producers a cut of that based on how much people take.
author: pilhofer

text: Well, the Gucci comparison just falls flat. Gucci sells through retailers, who pay Gucci a wholesale price. Apple News is a rev share. Consumers pay a flat rate to Apple, which pays publishers (after its 50% cut) based on some vague formula around usage.
author: pilhofer

text:
Going to reply to these individually because I don’t even know where to begin.

You do know how the App Store works, right? Completely agree on customer value. But Apple owns the customer in this case, not the NYT. Why would the NYT give up customers to Apple? No idea.
author: pilhofer

text: I dunno. Apple News is installed by default and only has 90M regular users (whatever that means). The Times alone does better than that online in a month. If the FT, WSJ, Guardian, NYT collaborated on a real Netflix for News like thing, I’m betting it would be pretty successful.
author: pilhofer

text: That’s an absurd comparison. Gucci is not a subscription business. The Times is. Gucci couldn’t care less who buys its product. The Times relies on having a direct relationship with their customers. Explain what possible benefit there is for the NYT here?
author: pilhofer

text:
The first sensible POV I have seen on Apple News’s subscription product. Why any quality publisher with a pay wall would do this is absolutely beyond me. 

Frankly, the NYT, FT and others should just get together and launch their own app.
author: pilhofer

text: Yep, agreed.
author: pilhofer

text: Yes. Just noting the difference.
author: pilhofer

text:
Yeah, but it’s not just ad placements; it’s ad products. I loaded up an NYT story on the 737 crashes this week and got an ad for a flight school. It happens. 

I do think there’s a bit of irony in a fact-checking site loaded up with ads that themselves need fact checking.
author: pilhofer

text:
Here’s the one membership appeal.

I’m not here to beat up on Poltifact, which is a site I admire and which, like everyone else, needs to find ways to keep the lights on.

I do think there’s certain kinds of ads that might not be right for a fact-checking site.
author: pilhofer

text: Then near the bottom of the page, you have Taboola. (Yes, there was a literal belly fat ad on the page when I visited.)
author: pilhofer

text: Sponsored content.
author: pilhofer

text: And it, of course, follows you down the page. Yow. Almost spilled my coffee as some very loud ad to visit Cleveland blasted out of my computer speakers.
author: pilhofer

text:
Over coffee decided to navigate to @PolitiFact this morning to read up on a couple of things. BOY did I regret that.

Content was great, but the ads? Oh my god. It’s pretty aggressive. And, well, a bit off-brand… I hate to say.

First, auto-play video ads with the sound on.
author: pilhofer

text:
Boy, I don’t recall this level of hand-wringing over whether the Starr report should be made public. 

Oh wait. That’s because there wasn’t.
author: pilhofer

text: You have to ask?
author: pilhofer

text: And amazing that cameras were present! Is that also a Texas thing? ;)
author: pilhofer

text: Literally every single thing about this product confuses me...
author: pilhofer

text: A biting retort!
author: pilhofer

text: Due respect to Debbie Harry, but WOW is this a tortured, misleading interpretation of what article 13 would do.
author: pilhofer

text: Be interesting to plot them on a paranoia scale. Apple/Facebook at the far end. Google way over on the other side. Twitter near FB — unless it’s Jack, and then it’s more trying to figure out what the heck he’s talking about. Maybe “Jackness" is the Y axis, actually.
author: pilhofer

text: I agree, though. It is strange and ultimately counterproductive from a PR standpoint because in lieu of actual information, you simply invite speculation. Silence is assumed to be covering something up—when in reality it might have been a stupid typo.
author: pilhofer

text: You’d know better than I, but isn’t that sort of chronic paranoia and secrecy kind of the norm in Silicon Valley? Certainly it is for Apple, around which an entire industry of Kremlinologists has formed. Google is in many ways the outlier in this regard.
author: pilhofer

text: Wow! Ok, question answered. :)
author: pilhofer

text: ... eligible for any taxpayer subsidy. There’s no way I am ok with tax dollars going to pad Digital First’s bottom like.
author: pilhofer

text: I would argue it also is about feeding a massive subsidy to private, for-profit companies. I have zero problem with government subsidies, but companies should be required to convert ownership of the paper into a foundation like the Philadelphia Inquirer to be ..
author: pilhofer

text: Why?
author: pilhofer

text:
You are old. 

Ok. We are old.
author: pilhofer

text: As a long-term goal, yeah. But like it or not, awards are one of the few ways project teams (esp investigative) can justify their existence to the bean counters. Who would otherwise see opportunity for cost-cutting. It’s stupid. Everyone knows it’s stupid. But it’s reality.
author: pilhofer

text: Unusually I get multiple sets as well. I feel like a failure when that happens, actually. But @SophieWarnes’s is probably right: we are just helping them train data. And there’s a lot of data to train.
author: pilhofer

text: Don't know about this one. They have the pipes, and have the machines. But do they have the games? That is a very big deal. There’s also a new wave of companies entering this market, including Sony, Nvidia… I don’t think we know how big this market is, even. Wait and see I’d say
author: pilhofer

text: Proudly so.
author: pilhofer

text: Congrats sir!!!
author: pilhofer

text:
Not without good reason.

Binary solo:  Zero zero zero zero zero zero one zero zero zero one one zero…
author: pilhofer

text: Fan-effing-tastic!!!
author: pilhofer

text: Maybe he can tell you. Hey, @CasparLS ... any truth to this?
author: pilhofer

text: Every time I do one of those recaptcha, I am not a robot things, I always have this Philip K Dick moment where I wonder… am I a robot? Would I even know? By selecting all these images with stop signs in them, am I violating some term of service? It’s freakin’ deep.
author: pilhofer

text: This is an important thread detailing some of the best reporting on tech. Sadly, this point about awards is all too true... and I think skews investigative projects into these near one-year chunks that don’t reflect the way the world works. Time to rethink criteria for awards.
author: pilhofer

text: Congrats! Great news for both of you.
author: pilhofer

text: Yeah. That launched in 2014. What I *think* is new is the membership language in all of their appeals across the site. That’s what’s interesting to me.
author: pilhofer

text: Have you no sense of decency sir?
author: pilhofer

text: That is until a highly underpaid moderator pulls down an iconic, disturbing photograph from the Vietnam war posted by a Norwegian news organization. Then we scream censorship!!!!!
author: pilhofer

text: Yeah, but that’s kinda sad too. Still, everyone loves a waterskiing squirrel.
author: pilhofer

text: If you are looking for logic, reason and consistency, you’re looking in the wrong place, my friend. British tabloids are to the UK as fire-breathing cable pundits are to the US. No surprise here whatsoever.
author: pilhofer

text: Jo, you have the power to ban people unilaterally, right? Surely this has to violate some term of service somewhere.
author: pilhofer

text: But then they did this very poorly, since all their traffic was on Twitter and completely unmonetized. That might be the saddest part of this story.
author: pilhofer

text:
"My fingertips tingle. My blood emulsifies.”

Yep, that sounds like the real thing, alright.
author: pilhofer

text: It is absolutely surreal reading a @jayrayner1 review of a Philadelphia cheese steak… in London.
author: pilhofer

text: Yeah, WSJ+ launched in 2014. What I am curious about is the membership-oriented wording of their more generic subscription appeals, like the ones you see on the homepage today. Maybe it’s been that way since 2014 and I have not noticed.
author: pilhofer

text:
So the WSJ launched WSJ+ back in 2014. It is membership in the Amex model: more transactional, and a lot less based on mission.

What I am trying to figure out is when the subscription prompts started leaning heavily into membership. Was it also around the same time?
author: pilhofer

text: Fascinating to see so many subscription-based publications adopting the language of membership. Not sure when the WSJ started using this language, but it is interesting.
author: pilhofer

text: Sounds delicious.
author: pilhofer

text: More butter! More toast!
author: pilhofer

text: Coverage. We need to cover the industry more completely than we are now.
author: pilhofer

text: Oh I see. You are saying better. I am saying more and better. We are close.
author: pilhofer

text: Ok, so now I’m confused by your original point. Yes, how media covers tech. You think we should be covering something else instead?
author: pilhofer

text:
Really? Cuz I think the entire discussion here was focused about 120 percent on how news orgs need to better themselves. 

(I dislike animated gifs, so just pretend I inserted one of, let’s say, a dog tilting its head repeatedly.)
author: pilhofer

text: Nope nope! I think it was the ill-considered toast-and-butter analogy.
author: pilhofer

text: I don’t think we are that far apart here. I think you think I’m making a point I am not. I’m not arguing for reducing scrutiny on anyone. (I might disagree with you on Amazon… I do think it has been under-covered.)
author: pilhofer

text: Agreed. And I should say, I do think we are seeing better coverage in certain places. Scrutiny of the board rooms, of VCs, gender inequity, tech culture, for example. There wasn’t much written about these things a few years ago.
author: pilhofer

text: Nothing here I disagree with at all. In fact, I think you’re making my exact point.
author: pilhofer

text:
Oh, is that what I said? ;)

Yeah, I’m pretty sure you know that isn’t my point. No one is excusing FB or Google here. I would just prefer to see the butter spread a bit more evenly on the toast, as it were.
author: pilhofer

text: Oh, sorry. Are we covering the tech sector in an informed, critical way now? It looks to me like mostly the same consumer tech fluff plus a ton of lightly informed finger-pointing at basically two companies. If there were a real effort to cover tech, I’d agree with you.
author: pilhofer

text: Here’s what someone needs to do when this happens to any network/cable commentator: track when and how quickly those advertisers come back when the dust settles.
author: pilhofer

text: This is your money graph. Absolutely 100 percent correct.
author: pilhofer

text: Agreed.
author: pilhofer
